issue.title: Nextjs Turbopack: assert is not defined

repository.name: tss-react
repository.description: ✨ Dynamic CSS-in-TS solution, based on Emotion

body:
I also came across this issue. 
Looks like turbopack doesn't know how to handle js block statements (tss-react uses block statements, both anonymous and labeled). There's some problem with imports not existing in the closure scope in that case. 

What I tried that worked:
- Assigning `assert` to a cost at the top of the file and using that instead of the import (although it fails at a different point later, didn't investigate that far down). 
- Replacing the block statements with IIFEs.

@omermizr,

Thank you **so much** for taking the time to identify the blocker here.  
I think it’ll be quicker on my end to remove the use of anonymous block statements from the library rather than wait for Turbopack to support them.  
That said, I’m genuinely surprised that Turbopack is being promoted as the default despite lacking support for such a fundamental language feature.

issue.title: ReferenceError: xxx is not defined

labels.name: linear: turbopack
labels.description: Confirmed issue that is tracked by the Turbopack team.

issue.body:
### Link to the code that reproduces this issue

https://github.com/Cygra/reproduction-example-with-markdown-it

### To Reproduce

1. Start the application in development (next dev)

### Current vs. Expected behavior

## Current

```
 ⨯ ReferenceError: isSpace is not defined
```

## Expected behavior

The application should start, since the method `isSpace` is defined and exported from the package "markdown-it".


### Provide environment information

```bash
Operating System:
  Platform: darwin
  Arch: x64
  Version: Darwin Kernel Version 23.6.0: Mon Jul 29 21:13:00 PDT 2024; root:xnu-10063.141.2~1/RELEASE_X86_64
  Available memory (MB): 16384
  Available CPU cores: 8
Binaries:
  Node: 20.18.1
  npm: 10.8.2
  Yarn: N/A
  pnpm: 9.15.0
Relevant Packages:
  next: 15.2.2-canary.0 // Latest available version is detected (15.2.2-canary.0).
  eslint-config-next: N/A
  react: 19.0.0
  react-dom: 19.0.0
  typescript: 5.8.2
Next.js Config:
  output: N/A
```

### Which area(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

Turbopack

### Which stage(s) are affected? (Select all that apply)

next dev (local)

### Additional context

_No response_

issue.title: fix(turbopack): Consider break label as conditional

body:
@timneutkens WOW!  
Thank you very much for investigating and fixing this.  
I was 100% planning on refactoring `tsafe` and `tss-react` to remove the use of named labels.  
I'm so glad you fixed it, since I use them in all my libs.
This closed issue has been automatically locked because it had no new activity for 2 weeks. If you are running into a similar issue, please create a new issue with the steps to reproduce. Thank you.
